reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “long views win” (asymmetric growth) consideration, arguing it backfires because patience may select for linear, uncompromising preferences that make moral trade harder and threats worse. This is a real internal-tension point, but it’s not very central to the essay’s main conclusions (which already treat WAM-convergence as unlikely and treat trade/threat dynamics as the key uncertainty), so centrality is modest. Strength is limited because the original text already anticipates much of the objection: it explicitly notes that non-discounting values needn’t be altruistic/correct, may not have time to dominate, and that linear/non-discounting regimes are where trade is least effective and threats bite hardest. So the critique mostly reframes/underscores a caveat rather than substantially refuting a relied-upon optimism pillar. It is largely correct as a reading, though it somewhat overstates how “intended” or how important the optimistic inference from asymmetric growth is in the essay. The argument is clear, focused, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Patient value selection may favor uncompromising rather than cooperative agents
